The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Sues for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Adem. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) el Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc

ESTABLISHED 1880
Editor and Manager - - R. Swelling
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1906

div.head: Egypt and Parliament
div.p: Today the Antemn Session of the Bristish Parliament will begin, and it is certain that Egypt will again shortly come to the front in the House of Commons for a section of the Literal Party do not appear to be inclined to leave this country alone Natal; India, New foundland and Malta have all been stirred up since the present Government came into Power, and judging from the fact that the closing day of the last session was taken up with a hot discussion about Egyptian matters, there is little likelihood that this country will fall to come in for a similar amount of attention in Parliament as it did during June, July, and August. There is some consolation for Anglo- Egyptian officials in the fact that Sir Edward Grey showed himself a zealous cham- pion of Lord Cromer's system of government, and it is, therefore, hoped that if there are to be any more discussions in Egypt he will be equally inclined to defend the present method of administrating the country. Consequently, in spite of all the clamour for a Constitution for Egypt, and the ontary raised over the hangings and floggings of Danishwal, Egypt will be allowed to go on pretty much as she did before for, with all its faults, it is generally recognised that the present system of patri- archal government of benevolent despotism, is the best suited for Egypt's need.

it is worth reminding those of our readers, who may expect great "reforms"to be executed here by the Liveral that it is only a year ago that Sir Elward Grey made the following declaration of his view with respect to the necessity for continuity in foreign policy -- I think it is important at the present moment to emphasis the need for continuity in foreign policy. I would not say that we are always bound, at all to advocate continuity in foreign policy. There have been times is the past when it was impossible. There may be times again in the future; but at the present time it is not only possible, but it is most important, to adhere to the principle of continuity. I wish, at the present moment to emphasize the fact that the friendship of the people of this coun- try is as sure and as well worth having as that of any monarch or autocratic Government in the world. I am conviced of this, that the next Government will not be backward in emphasis- ing that to the world at large"

div.head: MUDDLING IN EGYPT
div.p: In an article entitled "Muddling in Egypt" the "Globe" gives vent to some criticism of the Liberal Government which is very amusing reading to anyone acquainted with the con- dition of affairs in Egypt as it is based on a total misapprehension of the hearing of faota. A few days ago we announced that it was proposed to make the following additions to the Egyptian Army: One new Sudanese battalion will be formed. The strength of the Arab battalion will be increased and one company will be recruited of Kordofan Arabs and added to the camel corps. On the other hand, the cavalry will be reduced by one squadron.
This information was telegraphed to the "Times" and reproduced in the "Globe" where a writer seizes upon it to lash the Liberals as follows:

"The fundamental principle so strictly oberv- ed in India since the Mutiny, that the British portion of the Army should always bear a fixed ratio to the native portion, has also been the rule on the Nile up to the present. But a Cairo telegram in the "Times" indicates that our Radical Government de- termined to placate is anti-militarism ad- herents at any price, refuses to apply the prin- ciple any longer to Gegypt. While considerable augmentations of the native contigent are in process of being carried out, not one man is to be added to the British moiety. We should not feel surprised, indeed, if the strength were to be reduced on the pretext that the increases of the native furs rendered it un- necessary to maintain a large an English garrison. The farther excuse, always valid to the Radical intellect in cases of naval or military retrenchment, that economy will be promoted by substituting indigenous soldiers for alien, will probably be forthcoming in due course It adds to the mischievousness of this lunatid "reform" that the augmentation of the local forces includes a new Sudanese bat- tallion the material strengthening of the Arab battalion, and the raising of a company of Kordofan Arabs. While the excellent fight- ing quality of these several rooms is not open to question, they are wont to chafe at dis- ciplinary restraints when no war is on hand to employ their energies. They are profusely the sort of troops that require to be balanced during the monotony of peace times by the near neighbourhood of white soldiers. But instead of following continuity of military policy is that respect, the Cabinet deems it a product closing to increase the danger and to diminish the counter-check."

div.head: Tram Accident
div.p: A native had his head crashed on Sunday beneath the wheels of a tram at Shoabra,

div.head: Cairo.
Public Health Department.
div.p: MM. N. Joans, P. Angeliades and Isaac Efif, pharmacists, have been authorised to exercise their profession in Egypt.

div.head: Murderer Dies In Prison.
div.p: The watchman of the Cairo Tramway Company who murdered his wife at Bouluo on Friday by stabbing her thirty-five times, has died in prison

div.head: Egyptian Ostrich Feathers.
div.p: Out of 4,083 cases of ostrich feathers put up for sale at London at the beginning of the mouth 108 wen Egyptian", all of which were cold with good competition.

div.head: Fatal Fall.
div.p: A native plasterer working on the third foot of a new building at Mohatrem Bey, yesterday, lost his balance and fell into the street, being killed on the spot.

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: Daring the week ending last Saturday 14 lases of cattle plague were recorded, all of which proved fatal. Of these, 10 eases occurred at Fashn, 3 at Beoi Magar and 1 at Boba. Khedivial Law School
Me. Lambert, who was recently appointed director of the Khedivial Law School, arrived at Cairo yesterday afternoon and took up his new post this morning. He will also occupy the chair of penal law.

div.head: An Undesirable.
div.p: Iskender Kndsi, who had been exiled tor his assault on policemen of Abdin Caraool, Cairo, lately retained to Egypt end was seen in Alexandria. He was, however, rearrested, and shipped to Greece.

Um Rue Settlement The committee of the Londor Stock'Exchange have fixed Oct. 30th as a special settling day in Um Rns Gold Mines of Egypt, Limbed—133.843 shares of £1 each, its paid' (Nos. 8 to 133,849;.

div.head: Hashish Seizure.
div.p: A policemen yesterday discovered five parcels of hashish oh the Marina, near the Khe-divial Mail Line's offices. The smugglers are thought to be two Greeks who dropped the packages on the appearance of the policeman The Lancashire Fusiliers.

It is officially stated at Maltle, says the ' Daily Mail" correspondent, that (he 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers will not leave Egypt this month, as previously arranged. The battalion will probably return to Malta next December.

div.head: Yacht
div.p: The American S. Y. Aledo (673 tons), Captain 8.C. Lowland, arrived at Port Said on Sunday morning, coming last from Jaffa. Her owner is Mr. G. C. D. Beval. She sails on Thursday for Jaffa, and returns with a-party of American tourists who will go to the Capital.

div.head: A Turkish Conspiracy.
div.p: The Warsaw police have captured 20 young turks who recently arrived there for the purpose of studying revolutionary methods. They had intended levying contributions on Turkish residents and Mahomedans generally, for the purpose of initiating an insurrectionary movement in Constantinople.

div.head: Hellenlo Assizes.
div.p: The Hellenio Assize Conrt at Alexandria will re open its sittings on December 1, and amoDg other oases that will oome up for hearing are those of the Greek who murdered his aant at Fashn; Callicoponlos of Cairo, who tortured his servant girl to death; and * chemist who praotised without a lioenoe.

div.head: Murder Charge Dismissed.
div.p: A Cairo contemporary has it on good authority that the French Consular Court will dismiss the oaee of Paitlard, junior, who is aoonsed of murdering a Greek oafodji in Cairo, in view of the fact that tha bowabs of Maison Cioccolani are snspeoted.

div.head: state Railways.
div.p: The last issue of the "Journal Official" publishes an article of the Ministry of Public Works appointing Maoanley Bey General Manager of the Egyptian State Railways and Telegraphs. Maeaaley Bey arrived in Cairo yesterday from the Sudan.

div.head: Theft of Letters.
div.p: Giovanni Battista Vassalo, a British subject of Maltese origin, was brought before the British Consul at Cairo, Mr. A. D. Alban, yesterday morning, on the charge of appropriating letters which passed through his hands at the Cairo post office. Seven witnesses, whose letters had not been delivered, ever heard, after which the case was adjoined until Friday.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 19th October 5 vessels, of which 4 were northward and 1 southward bound, transited the Canal, and paid for transit and pas- | seoger toll Fr. 136,785.99. Of these 3 were British, 1 Anstiian, and 1 Fire soil. The total. receipts sines October 1 are Fr. 5,133,149 81, and daring that 138 vessels transited the Canal, 84 being northward and 104 southward bound.

The markaz will include the following villages, Delengaf, Razzif», Karnha, Atlamis-el-Kobta, Bbia-el-Hamra, I Kome-Zomrane, Hagar-el Mabronk, Zawiet, Mossalam, Khalilieh, Ezbet-e'.-Torieh Zawiet.' div.head: EGYPT AND CYPRUS
NEW MAIL CONTRACT SIGNED-
div.p: A Reuter's telegram form Cyprus states that the Government of the Island has signed a three years' contract with the Limassol Steamship Company for a weekly mail service between Egypt and Cyprus.

div.head: THE MEHKEMEH SHARIEH.
A CODE OF FOUR RITES.
div.p: According to the "Mokattam," the proposed codification of the Sheri (or religions law will embrace the four principal rites, and not exclusively that of the Hanafieh, which is the official rite of the Ottoman Empire. This code will not be submitted to the Council of Ministers and Legislative Body before the new regulations, now being formulated by a committee, are introduced into the system of the Mehkemeb Sharieh.

div.head: MOTOR BOATS FOR EGYPT-
INTERESTING experiments.
div.p: Messrs. Dixon Bros, and Hntohinson, Ltd', of Wbolston, ate sending out to Egypt very shortly three motor boats. One is the famous motor boat Hebe, the property of Capt. R. T., Dixon, who is sending her to Port Said for his: own one while in Egypt. She will be pat in the Water there and he proposes i run her up to Cairo himself by way of Ismailla and the Sweet Water Canal. She carries ample petrol in her tanks to do the journey from Port Said to Cairo without stopping, though it is possible that he may atop at one or two places on the way. He will very probably sell her when he returns to England.

Two other boats, which are the property of the firm, will be disembarked at Alexandriaabout the 8th prox. Out of these is a powerful motor launch, 30 ft. long with a 30 H.P. and 4- cylinder engine. She is designed as a pleasure boat, and would be suitable either for the in- the harbour At Alexandria or on the Nile at Cairo, or higher np. She has a speed of some all mile 8 an hour and would accommodate 8 or more people with comfort. She is built of teak throughout and would be capable of withstanding even a heavier sea than she .is likely to] meet with iDeide the breakwater at Alexandria. The third boat is designed for nose as a ferry boat or for the purpose of carrying cargo. 8he is built with a flat bottom and the engine placed right in the stern, so as to leave the whole of the center of the boat free for the accommodation of passengers or goods.

Mr. E. T. Dixon is coming out with these two boats to Alexandria and proposes to go out himself to Cairo by the Mahmondieh Canal. As the speed of the ferry boat is not so high as that of the fast motor boat (some 8 miles an hour), he will probably take two days over the journey. He expects to reach Cairo about the middle of the month.

div.head: CHITTY BEY'S APPOINTMENT.
div.p: "Al Abram" states that Chitty Bey's appointment to the Ministry of Fioanoe will only be temporary, and that he will shortly occupy the post of Financial Adviser to the Wakfs Administration. Rumour also says that the Wakfs Administration will shortly become a Ministry, as it was in the time of the Khedive Ismail.

div.head: SUDAN IRRIGATION.
div.p: A new grant of L.R 15,000 has been made to the Sudan Irrigation Service.
It is rumoured that Mr. Tottenham, assistant director of the Khartoum irrigation works, will send in his resignation shortly.

div.head: WELSH COAL FOR EGYPT.
div.p: Contracts for the supply of about 1,000,000 tons of coal, at unusually high prions, hate just been placed in South Wales, The Egyptian Railway contract, for the supply of 310,000 tons over nex.t year, is divided between Messrs. Pyman, Watson, and Co., Messrs. Watts, Watt", and Co., and Messrs. W. Milbnrn and Co., at an average ffob. price of from 14s. to 14s. 3d. per ton, less 2 per port.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: During the week ending last Saturday eight oases of bubonic plague were recorded for the whole of Egypt, of which three occurred at Alexandria, four at Suez, and one at Port Said.
The total number of oases recorded from the 1st January till the above date amounts to 500 against 264 and 817 in the corresponding periods of 1904 and 1905 respectively.
To-day's bulletin reports one recovery at Suez, and one admission to hospital at Port Said and Math.

div.head: QUARANTINE BOARD.
div.p: The Quarantine Board has decided to mention on the bills of health of steamers leaving Bgypt that oattle plagne now exists in the provinces of Minieh, Beni-Sonof, and Assioht, the previous annotation being oan- oelled,

div.head: THE YEMEN INSURRECTION.
DECLARATION OF A NEW IMAM. SULTAN'S OVERTURES TO REBELS.
div.p: Aden, October J5.

What may prove to be an important move in the Yemen is the self-selection of an, illiterate, indeed wholly undefeated, inhabit tent of Sada as Imam, who has declared himself as a loyal supporter Of the Sultan. I draw my information from a reliable 'and trustworthy merchant, who has recently arrived at Aden from Sana, and who declares the new to be officially reported in the Capital.

The city trom which springs this self-appointed Pritoe of Islatp lies in a plain about 150 miles north of Sana and is- strong- in fortifications. In it was the abode of the Imamu Mohamed Hamid end Din, who has been dared a usurper and expelled as such forgo the city, and against whom the newly-risen, priest has "openly declared hostilities.

Though disqualified for snob a post by the Moslem law, the new Imam has attracted the himself numerous supporters, chief among whom are many of the partisans of the fallen, and he has sent a despatch to Faizi Pasha, Governor-General of the Yemen, informing, him that he is organising forces to marefe •against the false Imam and attack him at Shahara, whence he has fled. Shahars, though only a small village, is 'strongly fortified, and was occupied by the Imam last year, when he drove the Turkish troops from -Sana. It is reported that he has transferred all his military, stores there and that be intends making a strong resistance.

Faizi Pasha has received strong assertions of loyalty to the Sultan –from the new Imam and his followers, who express their desire to promote the peace of the country, and, aa a guarantee of their faith, forces will be sent' to attack Shahara on both the northand sooth sides As ah 'expression of gratitude the Turkish General has sent the new Imam 3,000 dollars, with the promise that ,he will give him the assistance of his troupe in the near fritare.
Mistlan to Hamid Od Din

A significant move has also been made by the Sultan, who recently instructed Ali Ben' Abdallah, Sherif of Meoca, to form a special endeavour to pOtaiade him to (pay a visit to Yildiz Kiosk. The commission was- charged with pointing oat to the Imam that ths Sublime Porte oonld at any time send an overwhelming foroe into the Yemen to crash -alL rebellions, but hia Imperial Majesty desires to avoid the saorifioes of the thousands of lives, which snoh a step wonld coat The great aim of tLs mission was to be to induce the Imam to visit Stambonl. They were empowered to, guarantee his safety and as an evideuoe of this the Sherif of Meoca wonld aooompany him on hie journey, there-and hack.

But Sherif Ali, after making all-preparation for carrying out his Imperial Master's commands, was seized with a sndden illness and in his stead he sent his oonsin, Sherif Hamza, who, in company with the other members or the mission, left Mecoa abont the middle of last month.

Mohamed Hamid ed Din, however, rofoaed to grant the mission a personal interview, as is the way in Turkish diplomacy, and was. represented by his eldest son, who expressed his father's willingness to allow one ofHis sous to visit Yildiz Kiosk and negotiate with the Saltan. He mostly strongly affirmed that the Imam would,insist upon self-government for the Yemen, while recognising the Saltan as supreme head, and stated that, according to his proposals, the oonntry wonld pay an annual subsidy to Turkey.

It will observed by yonr readers that ib refusing to pay a personal visit to Tnrkey tba Iman felt that his return to the oonntry for whose freedom be is striving would bevety doubtful, whereas he is oonfident of toe'safety of his son. Shonld his representative foil to return in safety the possibility of a peaceful, termination to the Yemen insnrreotion would disappear until after tire death of Mohamed Hamid ed Din.

There - ic an bid 'Arab proverb regarding "singing in the ears of a deaf'mans'' and'toe oonferenoe of the loan's representative with the Saltan will doubtless have the same effect, as one oaanot.prasame that bis .proposals will, reoeive consideration.
It is rumoured too,that Falsi Pknba sttbngly disapproves of the 'Sultan's Toafosion to'the Imam and that he is about to resign his post.
The mission, headed -bySherif Hamza, has returned to Mecoa vi Hbdeidu.

div.head: EGYPT'S INSECT PESTS.
AN INTERESTING YEAR BOOK.
div.p: The Khedivial Agrionltnral Pooiety has just issned its Year Book for 1905. The work marks a forther advance in the history of Egyptian scientific publications, and can be cordially reoommenaed to all soientifio agriculturists. It is printed ;n a manner that doe* an infinity of oredit to the National Printing Press. The illustrations are excellent, some of the oolonred figures of ootton pests, painted by Miss Beard, being remarkably grod, and the varions contributions to the volnme are'dearly and carefully compiled and seldom overweighted by a highly soientifio terminology.

The first, and in many ways the most important, part of the volnme deals With the insect, pests which infeot the Egyptian ootton orop. Mr. F. C. Willoooks, entomologist to the Khe- divial Agrionltnral Society, is responsible for the hundred and nineteen pagea in which the' life history and-tbe etnietare of a -number of- cotton-devonring speoies are described with the nature of their ravage* pnd the pwventivedr remedial measure? that have been found most effioaoions in oheoking their multiplication. The Berios of Btndies prepared by Mr. Willoooks refleot great oredit both opon him and upon Mr. F. V. Theobald, vice-principal of toe Sonth Eastern Agricultural College, under whom he studied economic 'entomology. The cotton-worm moth, the Cot-worm moth Agrotis ypsibon, the small but destrutctive larva of Carddrina exigua, and the boll-worm moth, Earicus msulana, are all described'and figured, and in the case of the last-named insect wrcre famished with a large Unmher of new and extremely valuable data.

The habits, the appearanoe, and the ravages of the tree cotton-worm 'have already been described 'In oUr columns. FOr the last two years the Mihistry of the'lnterior'have nlsned nseful pamphlets on the sUhjbot, and legislation has aided1 science in the struggle fast this pest. Like Mustapha Pawns HSanrel, Prodenia littoralis has had an admirableadvertisement, end from a nuisance has become a notoriety. Inspeetore, otodehs.mamonrs. retired officers and tropa of small boys go forth every summer to combat the mseot, which, had it an intellect, might feel a oertain pride in being ranked with the Phylloxera, Gie Colorado beetfo, the -wire worm, and-the- San Joed seals

div.head: The Boll worm,
div.p: But the boll worm Is more dangerous. Its habits and size make its depredations less visible and less preventible. While the cotton worm, or the groups of eggs laid by the parent moth, oan be taokfed by small boys, the minute larva of the green boll-worm moth is invisibl* onoe it has sored into the shoots, squares, or bolls of the cotton plant. Its habitat savM'tt' from the attacks of natural epemhw, to which I it is only exposed when learriug one reedihg ground for another, or while preparing its eeocon on toe exterior of the plant. Ite ravages are on an average more serions. Iu. 1906 it destroyed well nigh a quarter of the

crop in Upper Egypt. Its yearly ravages, reckoned by what Mr. Willoooks describes as a moderate estimate, represent a lose of nearly a million sterling. 'It is the moire difficult to oppose, in that the first conspioooua warning of its presOnch is'thu wasting of thei boll Or the wilting of the shoot which it has attacked. Ite defection demands, a trained eye. the external traces of its presenoe being at first almost miorosoopio, and the task of picking all snspeoted bolls ever areas of several hundred feddans wonld overtax any but the richest cultivators. Even if the wilted shoots attacked in May, before the bolls havU formed, were pluoked, there oould be no guarantee against farther depredations, for toe eggftof the moth are not all laid simultaneously. The well-grown worm might have left a wilted shoot to pupate : the immature lam might have shoWn no trace of ite presence.

div.head: Preventitive Measures.
div.p: How, then, is this pest to be combated in the absence of any effioaoions remedies 1 Only by preventive measures which will oheok its increase or reduce its numbers in the winter months. The oonolnsicin of Mr. Willcooks' study of the insect is of such importance to agriculturist'? that we venture to quote at length:—

"It has already been pointed out that there' is a considerable amount of evidence'to show that E. imularn is active doting the winter months, and tides over from one ootton season to 'another on Bfray plants belonging to the, order Afahaceai, viz, the garden hibisous,; volhnfeer growths of cotton, bamia, and tehl. This being the case, it is clear that every effott- shduld be made to do away with these plants daring the winter and early spring panths in the cotton areas. This applies more especially to the last three plants, although in some oases the garden hibisons may play a considerable part in helping the peet It wonld he diffionlt to do away with these ornamental shrnbs altogether; hoWevez they could be kept pinned back, in order to prevent the presence of bad it from which the surrounding cotten could be infected.

With regard to the other three, no disunity, should be experieDoed. All that is needful ia thdroogh 'dear, farming.' The tehl should be palled op by the roots and never ent. The, states should be made nse of at . as e?rly a date as possible, and all growths arising from shed, sews should be rigorously kept down. The same applies to bamis, which should not he grown as a perennial anywhere in toe neighbourhood of cotton fields; otherwise 'it will provide early food for the bollworm. In the onto of ootton this should not be, left standing longer than is necessary. All volunteer, grdwths of ootton which arise from roots which were ont as well ae from shed seeds should be kept down.

If then measures are eldrtly adhered to enthalpy should do a great deal towards keeping this pest in check, but till we know for certain that E. insulama has no other ways of passing the winter it is quite impossible to say that it will ba entirely effective. Theoate expended on clehn forming might be augmented wrth benefit by putting into praotice the dead shoot picking method in May andJone if ooltiva- torb find it praotioable .....

In conclusion we msy state that it is essen tie! that onltivators reslire the bollworm to be a reality and that nearly all the damage, nsnsttyrneribed- to fog, is canned by its ravages. They must make themselves oonversant with the life-history and habits of the depredator and wake observations and axperirascls in oodtrolling it themselves."

div.head: KAMEL ON FRENCH PRESS.
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Kamel writes in Al Lewa" : -For months part a section of the French Press in Egypt has followed an entirely new tine, devoting itself to attacks on feb nation, which it accuses of faults that it does not possess, fanaticism among, them, flow (attitude will astonish all Of us who owe our education to France, and still fariher diminish onr sympathy with that nation in This Motion of the Press attacks as for demanding oni freedom. In its eyes we remain- mere children as yet, unfit to enjoy the hleering of liberty and self government. So France's coutnry long efforts have been a failure. For, otherwise, how could France Eire enooaraged Oar Government to educate the Egyptians to formand perfect military forces, to' dOnetrnot barrages, to boild dykes and dig Canals to improve onr agriculture, industry and oomtrferos to a word, to strengthen its power generally, when French journalist? 6f to day dOeerihe ns-as beings unfit for independence t And If its are, why did Franoe work for 33 years to raise ae end to gain for ns onr autonomy 1 Franoe, who jbas declared more that Onoa that we were ripe for self-govetnmant and that we .poafessdd men in every way fit to rale? Why did she lay her hand on dare ; why did ehe encourage it with every species of promise?

div.head: NEW ARABIC REVIEW.
div.p: Mahmoud Taher Effendi Hakt, who-beeamS known to the reading pnblio by his recent book the Virgin of Denlshtrsi,'has pushed the first number of a new weekly review in Cairo, to which he gives the title of A1 Djaneedeh el labouyeh." In his opening remarks the Editor says that it will be the aim of his journal to give sincere advice to the people of Egypt end point out to them their weeks esses in politioal, eooiil, financial, and moral questions. One of the most sinking of this first number refers to the Toroo-Greek war, by which Greece regained her independence. The writer deals in detail with the battle of Mavarino, which took plaoe on October 80, 1827, recalling how severely the Ottoman fleet suffered from the force which England, France, and Russia thrust against her. He deals seven- ly with Lord Byron, whom he aoeneee of gran fanaticism, for the part which he played in the incitement of the Greek revolutionaries in whose cause he met his death.

div.head: THE HOUSE OF LORDS. IS IT THREATENED? SPEECH BY MR. BALFOUR.

div.p: Mr. Balfonr, (.peaking at Manchester, dealt it length with the Government's policy in antrodnoing a mass of impossible measures in order to accumulate, what the Radicals termed, a "oase against the Lords." The Radioals proposed on these grounds to ask their constituencies to sanction a ohange in the constitution of the country. Mr. Balfoor said that be regarded with the greatest serenity the threats against the House of Lprds. (Reuter)

div.head: COUNT GOLUCHOW8KIS RESIGNATION. A HUNGARIAN VICTORY

div.p: Count Goluchowski has resigned. His departure is considered as a Hungarian viotory. It is possible Herr von Aereothal will replace him. (Hanot)
The Esaperor Francis Joseph has accepted pchowski's resignation. (Reuter)
M. Fallife.es has received M. Iswolsky.
M. Clemeaceau continues to take steps for the tormatiuin of a Ministry. M. Millerand is spoken of as Minister for Foreign Affairs. MM. Poincarfe and Bourgeois have definitively withdrawn. (Havas)
M..CIemenceao has created a new Ministry. The Labour member, M. Caillaox, has accepted the post of Minister of Finance. {Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN GOVERNMENT. A PARLIAMENTARY MINISTRY IMPOSSIBLE.
BANKRUPT'S SAD END.THROWS HIMSELF UNDER TRAIN.

div.p: Mr. Maofayden committed snioide by throwing himselk under a train, close to Moorgate Street station, on Saturday.- His body was terribly mutilated. No statement of his affairs can be made; as the deceased was the only partner of thlp firm in England. (Peater)
Fifteen business buildings have been de strayed. Damage to the extent of £100,000 has been done, uf which £73,500 is oovered by
insurance. (Reuter)

div.head: COLONEL MORGAN RETIRED.
div.p: Lieut.-Colonel H. G. Morgan, C.B., D.8.O., A.8.C., who is so well known in Egyp', is one of the (dicers who have teen called onto retire by the Army Connoil, in coDneotion with the War Stores Scandal Lient-Colonel Morgan received bis first ccmnoission in the Army Servioe Corps on Dec. 5, 1883, and attained his present rank in Febroary of last year. He has had a distingnished career in the branch of the service to which be belonged, having received a C.B. and been appointed a member of the Distingnished Servioe Order, besides being mentioned several times in despatches. His only war service was in the Dongola Expedition, nnder Lord Kitchener (then Sir Herbert Kitchener), but he has been employed in administrative work of great importance and responsibility. At the olose of the Boer War he was sent to Sonth Afrioa in connection with the onerons task of arranging for the disposal of the enormous stock of war stores which had been aconmnlated. On his return from Sonth Afrioa Colonel Morgan was appointed Director of Supplies. The incidents in conDtc'icn with this work, disclosed at the itqairy condaoted by the War 8tores Com mission, do not rcqnire recapitulation, but it may be mentioned that Colonel Morgan was commended for his services in South Africa, and was awarded a Companionship cf tho Bath.

div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS. REPRESENTATIVE GOVERNMENT
div.p: Stevenson said somewhere that "man does not live by bread alone, bnt principally by catchwords," and such seems to he the ease with the vernaoolar Press in its obsession that representative government is the panacea for Egypt. All theee newspapers labour under the impression that constitutions oan be grafted on nations like buds on trees.

This attitude efmind is common to all races and nations whote political education is undeveloped, and when the leading native newspapers persist in believing that Egypt oan be endowed forthwith with a beautiful system of representative government, it is only another proof of their complete inexperience of the length tf time rcqnired for the evolution of representative institutions. "A! Moayad," in a recent leading article, remarked :—

"Now that the faults of absolute government in Egypt have appeared in their glaringly disgraceful colours, and that it has been proved to all the people of Egypt and England that an absolute governor, however honourable, kind, and inolined to justioe, cannot govern the conntry in which he works as he desires, since the oharaot9rs of those who work under him may deviate from the conrse of his own inclinations so mnoh that in one work two opposites meet—willing to do good and do ill, propriety of the head and bad oondnot of the staff1, humanity of the commander and ornelty of the bidden—faults of officials whiph remain I hidden behind theenrtain of the high qualities of the chief, for a long or short time, nntil the growth of these fanlts toms them! into atro- cities too big to remain unseen Behind that curtain; for these reasons Egyptcannot prosper under one man who is good or likes to be good. On the other hand its progress and prosperity can rnly be achieved by the help of a representative government sonnd and containing all the powers of snch a government snoh as has been recommended by H. M. the King of England to have been theoanse of the advanoe, happiness, and prosperity of all the oolonies that enjoyed it,

"We mean that representative government that defends itself, that it corrects the fanlts of officials and watohes them with its influence. We mean that representative government that every Egyptian should work for and demand, that representative government which we have been promised by the representative of the mighty British Crown in 1882, when he advised the Khedive to abolish the Egyptian Representative Honse and establish the Legislative Council, the General Assembly, and the District Councils as preparatory regnla- tions for the representative government in all its senses. We mean that representative government the realization of which was demanded by the General Aseembly, and asked to be decided upon by the Khedivial Government in 1901 at a time when the need for it was not as apparent as it iB now. The fntnre life and happine's of the nation depend on that representative government. The realization of that hope by the representatives ol Eoglish ii fluecee in Egypt is the strongest proof that England wishes onr welfare, and that she is far from wishing ns to be a prey in the jaws of absolute governors." i
MAJOR POWELL-COTTON'S
EXPEDITION.

Letters dated KaBindi, August 20, have been received by Renter's Agenoy from MnjorPowell- Cotton who nearly two years ago left England on an expedition from the Nile to the Zambesi. For no less than ten months Major Powell- Cotton and his wife have been living among the Pygmies of the Congo Forest, where the explorer haB been stndying the dwarfs and oollectiDg. He has succeeded in preserving the skin of a fine ball okapi, and has secured a large collection of other forest animals. At the time of writing Major Powell Cotton was about to proceed to the sonth of Lake Albert Edward, a region said to bs fall of lions, rhinooeri, and other big game.
"IMPRESSIONS" OF EGYPT.

"Red Letter DayB in Greece and Egypt" is the title given by Mr. 0. H. Hardy to a book of "Impressions" gathered during a tour in these delightful countries. While the work oontains nothing that is new, it is brightly written, and will appeal to those who have not had the pleasure of visiting Egypt and the Near Eiet, and are perforoe compelled to obtain seoond hand impressions of the countless features of interest opened up to the traveller in these lands. The section devoted to Egypt oontains chapters on Cairo and the Pyramids, the University of Cairo, and Thebes, which are illustrated with several very dear photographs, and will prove interesting reading, especially at the present time, to those abent to make a trip to Egypt this winter.Tbe work iB published by Messrs. Sherratt & Hughes, 60, Chandos St., W C.,

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
